para.paratext: Under O.C.G.A. § 24-2-220, a court may take judicial notice of administrative regulations provided that they have been filed with the Secretary of State.

Many regulations of administrative agencies of the state are admissible in evidence by statute.[1] Also, the Georgia Supreme Court has made it clear that trial and appellate courts must take judicial notice of those rules and regulations of administrative agencies as required by the Administrative Procedures Act (O.C.G.A. § 50-13-8) unless the issuing agency is explicitly excluded from those provisions by O.C.G.A. § 50-13-2(1). The court may not take judicial notice of excluded agency rules and regulations.[2]

Clements v. Seaboard Air Line Ry. Co., 158 Ga. 764, 124 S.E. 516 (1924) (public service commission); Turner v. Brunswick Distributing Co., 95 Ga. App. 651, 98 S.E.2d 591 (1957) (revenue commissioner); Davis v. General Gas Corp., 106 Ga. App. 317, 126 S.E.2d 820 (1962) (state fire marshal). Joel Properties, Inc. v. Reed, 203 Ga. App. 257, 416 S.E.2d 570 (1992) (Georgia State Building Code is not a rule or regulation of which a court could take judicial notice).

The Georgia Administrative Procedure Act requires that judicial notice be taken of any rule, which has become effective pursuant to the provisions of that act. See O.C.G.A. §§ 50-13-2(a), 50-13-8; Beall v. Department of Revenue, 148 Ga. App. 5, 251 S.E.2d 4 (1978) (rules of the State Merit System); Dix v. State, 156 Ga. App. 868, 275 S.E.2d 807 (1981).

State v. Ponce, 279 Ga. 651, 619 S.E.2d 682 (2005), involved regulations of the DMVS or Public Service Commission, neither of which state agencies are exempted from application of the APA provisions, and the rules and regulations were properly adopted by those agencies. The subject rules and regulations were required to be judicially noticed by the courts. O.C.G.A. § 50-13-8.
